config.title: An Introduction to Student-Centered Peer Education

details.text: Welcome!
This training, “Introduction to Student-Centered Peer Education,” was designed for anyone who is working in an academic support capacity with other students.

In this training, we use the term “peer educator” as a general term because it can apply to a range of types of positions. You may be tutoring, mentoring, coaching; working as a learning assistant, teaching assistant or peer advisor; or engaging in some other form of peer-to-peer education. Whatever the role, you’re preparing for right now, this training can provide valuable information, ideas, and opportunities to practice your approach to working with others.

The term “peer educator” begins with the term “peer.” While a common interpretation of “peer” is based on having a similar age, status, grade or ability, our use of the term describes the type of relationship that the educator has with the student: co-learner, an equal.

While peer educators may not necessarily be of the same age or grade, they engage with the student in a relationship that has the potential to create an approachable and open dynamic which can amplify the student’s learning.

All this to say, regardless of the title of your position and the type of work you’re doing, the fundamentals from this training can be relevant if you are working with a student in an academic support capacity.
Training Development & Collaboration
A dynamic and diverse team of trainers, supervisors, and peer educators at Oregon State University collaborated to develop this training.
Let’s meet the folks who contributed to this work!
The content was written by our team of primary authors:

We received invaluable contributions from a dedicated group of reviewers: Charlie Beckers, Marjorie Coffey, Alexsandra Cortés, Chris Gasser, Todd Gibbs, Dr. Elizabeth Jones, Jeff Kenney, Caitlin McVay, and Sarah Norek.
Five experienced peer educators offered perspectives, ideas, and examples of how they approach their work with students.

"My name is Ruta and I’ve been a tutor and academic coach for a year. I enjoy working as a peer educator as a way of collaborating with students to help with their academic success and providing them an opportunity to build on their skills academically. Personally, it has been helpful working alongside the students because I’ve adopted some new learning techniques as well."
details.caption: Ruta

details.audioTranscript: This audio clip contains no sound

details.text: "My name is Abbey. I’ve been an academic coach at Oregon State for two years. I also have several years combined experience working as a teacher’s assistant, life skills peer tutor, and math tutor. My favorite thing about being a peer educator is getting to see and take part in the process of students discovering solutions for themselves that they didn’t even think possible prior to our conversations."
details.caption: Abbey

details.audioTranscript: This audio clip contains no sound

details.text: "My name is Conner and I’m a Junior here at Oregon State University majoring in Bio-Health Science with a minor in Chemistry and partaking in the Medical Humanities Certificate program offered here at OSU. I tutor the hard sciences some of which include General Chemistry, Organic Chemistry, and Biology. I’ve been an academic coach for one year, and I fell into this role given my profound adoration for the position. I’m extremely passionate about what I do, and what I value most is facilitating the success of students here at OSU while unleashing their fullest potential. Getting to witness deep enrichment, and assisting in the understanding of the coursework in which I tutor allows for an engaging environment that strongly fits the mission of the EOP program in which I tutor for. These reasons among many, are why I chose to be an EOP tutor."
details.caption: Connor

details.audioTranscript: This audio clip contains no sound

details.text: "My name is Dylan and this is my third year as a tutor for TRiO. I am a senior studying to become a math teacher, so tutoring seemed to be a good introduction to becoming an educator. Being able to help students learn challenging material and pushing them to think deeper about concepts are two of my favorite aspects of being a tutor."
details.caption: Dylan

details.audioTranscript: This audio clip contains no sound

details.text: "My name is Paola Mendoza and I’ve been an academic coach at OSU for the last two years. I am a senior pursuing double degrees in Psychology and Sociology. What’s been the most inspiring for me as a peer educator and an academic coach is being able to assist students in looking at a problem or a goal from a new perspective, in order to reach a resolution or a new strategy for success."
details.caption: Paola

details.audioTranscript: This audio clip contains no sound

details.text: We are grateful for to OSU Ecampus and Open Oregon State for their work developing this training infrastructure.

None of this would have been possible without the generosity of the OSU Women’s Giving Circle. Their funding allowed for our inclusion of student voice, perspectives, and ideas throughout this training.
An Overview

In this training you will be learning about a range of topics all aimed to prepare you to accomplish three objectives when working as a peer educator. Each time you set to work with a student, we believe you have the opportunity to deliver on three key objectives during your time with that student:
Support the student in recognizing their own capacity as a learner/student
Engage the student in thinking strategies and activities to master content
Help the student to identify tools and resources available to them

There are many ways to achieve these objectives in your sessions. This training is structured as three units, each introducing strategies and ideas that you can implement to achieve those objectives in your sessions, and each building off of the previous.
Unit 1 covers some foundational elements we use when supporting another student’s learning, including some communication and relationship-building strategies.
Unit 2 explores different ways you can help students learn material and master content through collaborative learning activities.
Unit 3 examines the structure of a peer education session and identifies ways to connect students to additional resources and tools.
Before we dive into the content, here’s a bit more information about our approach and the structure of the units.
Our Approach

We believe there are a lot of ways to be an effective peer educator. Our goal in this training is to demonstrate some key concepts and skills, give you some examples of how our peer educators approach their work, and give you space to reflect on your own approach.

Because there is not one way to be a good peer educator, your best work will be a combination of finding your authentic voice as a peer educator, getting to know the student or students with whom you’re working, and figuring out how to adapt your style so it will resonate with them.

Throughout this training module, you will be reading much of the content in the platform, scrolling through as you go. We encourage you to take your time and go slowly. It can be easy to keep scrolling without thinking about what you’re reading, but to get the most out of the material, we urge you to pause and reflect.
As you work through the material, it may be helpful to think to yourself:
How does this idea or concept reinforce something I already believe or know?
How does this idea or concept challenge something I already believe or know?
What tangible strategies from this unit can I adopt that will help me be more effective when working with another student?

Because we value your thinking as an important part of the learning process, we’ve built note-taking and reflection into the training. At the beginning of each unit, we’ll ask you to download or print a note-taking and reflection guide. Throughout the training, you’ll see this symbol indicating it’s time to pause for a moment and fill out the corresponding section in your notes sheet.

Your notes will create a resource you can use as you continue to work as a peer educator. Additionally, if your supervisor has asked you to complete this training, they may ask you to submit your reflection notes as a confirmation that you’ve completed each section.
Throughout each unit, you’ll notice a few other features:

We’ve included a number of examples from peer educators in the form of videos and audio recordings to show you a range of different styles. Try to notice the range of approaches and think about your own style.

Along the way, you’ll encounter interactive elements designed to give you a chance to think ahead about ideas before revealing a possible response, example or answer. There isn’t one right answer to these prompts, but we’ve given you some ideas we came up with and hope you’ll treat these activities as opportunities to practice your thinking as well.

Research, theory, and literature from the field of education and psychology provide an important backbone for this work. We’ve woven some key concepts in the content, and if you’d like to read more about them, check out the citations and further reading at the end of each unit.
We know you’re already coming in with some great skills and experiences. This training gives you a chance take those skills to the next level.
Thank you for engaging in this training - we’re excited to be part of your learning and development as a peer educator.
And know that we’re already grateful for the work you do and the contributions you make to the learning and success of others! Thank you for being a peer educator!
Ready to get started?

sections.title: Unit 1: Foundational Elements for Working Together

details.text: This unit explores some foundational elements we use when supporting another student’s learning.
details.alt: People having a conversation in a hallway

details.text: Before you begin Unit 1, please click on the "Download" button below to download/print a note-taking sheet.
Unit 1 Reflection Guide

Remember, this is a tool for your learning and a resource you can use as you continue to work as a peer educator. Additionally, depending on your training format, your supervisor may ask you to show or submit your reflection notes as a confirmation that you’ve done the work.

Many people assume that the key elements of successful peer education are based on knowledge of how to teach and the subject matter itself. While those are important, and we will talk more about those in the following units, the base of successful support also has to do with the relationship you build together.

If you think back to some of the experiences you’ve had that felt most “helpful” - you may notice the importance of feeling listened to and feeling like the other person cares about your success. In contrast, perhaps you can remember a time when you didn’t feel listened to or supported.

In her 1999 study, researcher Marcia Baxter Magolda asked students to “describe teaching environments that they found helpful in promoting their learning.” She discovered as a theme that students appreciated when teachers showed:

cards.revealText: Click here to reveal the results

details.text: While this looked different from student to student - the theme still emerged as an important element of her research and has been found in subsequent studies.
In 2000, researcher Geneva Gay demonstrated that a caring relationship can impact the outcomes of learning. Her research indicated that:

cards.revealText: Click here to see what the research indicated
cards.text: Caring makes people more willing to participate
cards.textThree: Caring prompts student effort and hard work

details.text: Reflection #1 - Fill out this section on your Notes Sheet

A caring and supportive interaction can also enhance students’ sense of belonging at the institution, which is then magnified by the new levels of success they experience. This sets a positive cycle in motion, where care and accomplishment mutually reinforce student success.

With that in mind, the first unit “Foundational Elements for Working Together” focuses on the interpersonal and communication-based elements that we use when working with and supporting another student’s learning.
For Unit 1, we have chosen five important topics that provide the foundation for working with another person.
Listening and Being Present
Asking Questions and Prompting Thinking
Seeking Clarification
Validating Others
Building Self-Awareness

At first glance, these topics might seem like basic skills you use everyday, but when used well, they form the core of effective helping. No matter where you’re at currently, consider increasing your capacity and proficiency beyond what you already do. As you engage with each of these skills, think to yourself, what would the next level of this skill look like?
And keep in mind - these are foundational teaching skills. All of us continue to hone them because we use these skills every day in our work and in our relationships.
Click on each skill below to reveal some simple examples of how they are honed in different contexts

browser.htmlContent: Teachers become self-aware to avoid making assumptions or judgements about where a student falls on the learning spectrum
Good leaders ask questions in order to reflect on past experiences, receive feedback, and identify future goals for the team
In your personal life with family, friends, or significant others, you can seek clarification in order to avoid misunderstandings
Supervisors can use validation to motivate and encourage their employees
Teachers become self-aware to avoid making assumptions or judgements about where a student falls on the learning spectrum
Choose a tab above to display more information

details.text: There are many different ways to "listen" and everybody has a way of listening that is slightly different. Here are three concepts related to listening we will explore:

columns.text: Is your mind ready to listen to someone else?
How do you demonstrate that you are listening?
What are you hearing when you listen?

details.text: Are you ready to listen?
Being ready to listen is a mental activity; when you’re listening you are:
Mentally and physically focused on the person in front of you so that you best understand their words and meaning, and create space so they may talk from their own experience.
And you avoid:
thinking about what you’ll say next
thinking about random other things
starting a critique, counter-argument or rebuttal in your head
working on another task (like packing up or looking at your phone)
diagnosing the problem or root cause
Hear from our peer educators how they’ve improved their listening over time.
A key component of listening is silence.  Here’s some silence to listen to:

details.audioTranscript: This audio clip contains no sound

details.text: What was your reaction?
Did you find the silence calming? Relaxing? Exciting?
Did it make you anxious? Susicious? Annoyed?

Everyone has a different relationship to silence but it is an important part of a tutoring session. It’s giving the student time to think independently. Silence is what creates space in the conversation for the other person to talk. It’s what allows you to listen.
You can even say, “take a moment and think about [topic or questions]” - making the silence more comfortable for the student.
How do you demonstrate that you're listening?
Listening looks different for everyone and it’s hard to tell if someone is listening based on the way they look.

details.imageAlt: A variety of images of students

details.text: Even so, it helps build credibility and connection if the student gets the sense that you are fully and actively listening and can help them feel comfortable talking and sharing with you.

browser.htmlContent:
• Remove physical barriers (ear buds), and orient yourself physically towards the person.
  • Don't interrupt or talk over the other person.

• Use your own preferences as a starting point. What helps you know someone is listening?
  • Use facial expressions, space/proximity, silence, varied eye contact, nodding, and other nonverbal communication.
  • Use verbal cues like "mmhmmm" or "I see what you mean"
  • Allow a pass after they finish speaking.

• Develop an awareness of how the student you work with listens.
  • Pay attention to how your own listening behavior is received - do they seem uncomfortable?
  • Learn about mirroring.
Select okay, good or better to learn more...

details.htmlContent:
• We’ve talked about how to mentally prepare yourself to listen, how to demonstrate that you’re listening to the other person, and finally we’ll practice listening.
  • When people speak, they offer a lot of information. In the following clip, listen to the speaker and think about the questions we ask on the right side.
  • Practice listening for those different layers of information!.
details.alt: A student helping a fellow student using a computer

details.text: Listening Activity - What are you hearing?

details.audioTranscript: This is a transcript of the audio file for accessibility

details.text: Listen to this clip and consider the following questions below.
What is she talking about? What is happening in this scenario?
What is her perception of what is going on? What observations or information does she offer?
What do you think she is feeling? What did you pick up on from her tone and words?
I don't know what I'm doing wrong, I'm a sophmore now and I've been getting really bad grades since my first term here. My GPA was 2.0 after my first term, which is not okay...
Content, information: not happy with current grades; essay or short answer exams go better; taking math and chemistry this term.

I got A's and B's in high school. Since then I've been studying harder and harder, and I actually do understand the material! When I work with classmates on math or chemistry problems and participate in clas, I know what I'm talking about, but my grades don't show that.
Perception: feels like she's working hard already; fellts like she does know the material; high school was easier.

If I had studied this hard in high school, I would've gotten all A's, so I really don't understand what's going on. The only time my grades are semi-okay are when there are essay or short answer exams, but the rest is just bad.
Feelings or emotions: frustration, confusion, annoyed that the hard work isn't paying off.

details.audioTranscript: This is a transcript of the audio file for accessibility

details.text: Optional: Want to practice listening to another scenario? Click the play button above.
So far, we've had a chance to talk about
Being mentally present while listening
Demonstrating to the other person that you're listening
Identifying what you're hearing when you're listening
Before we move on, we have an additional idea to consider on what it means to listen to and understand someone else:
We’ve all had conversations in which we’ve had to work hard to understand the person speaking due to a range of factors - background noise, style of speaking, accent, word choice.
The good news? It turns out you can train your brain to listen and understand.
First, listen to this quick clip:

details.audioTranscript: This is a transcript of the audio file for accessibility

details.text: Was that clip difficult to understand? It was for us! Now, listen to this clip:

details.audioTranscript: This is a transcript of the audio file for accessibility

details.text: Reflection #2 - Fill out this section on your Notes Sheet
Our takeaway?

The more you work with someone, the more easily you’ll understand each other. Our brains are capable of adapting how we listen & process when someone else is speaking. Be aware of when you need to work harder to listen and embrace that experience as a new opportunity.
Now that we've learned a bit about listening, let's continue.
In the next two units, you’ll notice we often rely on questions to facilitate learning. There are many different ways to ask questions, let’s explore!
Here's why:
We use questions because:
Asking questions allows the students to engage actively in the learning process.
Asking a question allows the student to practice thinking - otherwise the student may not have an opportunity to speak or participate in the learning.
Asking questions empowers the student to do the work themselves.
But questions are also helpful as you build a relationship with your peer. They convey messages like:

details.imageAlt: Students working collaboratively with a laptop

details.text: We said "asking questions," but we actually mean:
Open-Ended Questions

Open-ended questions are phrased to invite the other person to provide more of a response than a “yes” or no,” giving you a chance to hear more of their thinking and giving the student a chance to think more deeply themselves.
Examples:
What do you notice about the problem or question?
How would you like to approach our time together today?
What is the relationship between concept A and concept B?
Hear some example questions that peer educators ask at the beginning, middle, or end of their session or conversations with students:
Open-Ended Prompts

details.htmlContent:
Some of the most effective open-ended questions aren’t questions at all.

An open-ended prompt is a statement that invites the student to engage in thinking or talking.

Examples:

  • Tell me about what you’ve been working on since we last met.
  • Let’s talk through the problem up to the point you get stuck.
  • Describe what you already know about what the exam will be like.

details.text: Listen to our peer educators demonstrate some of the prompts they use through their sessions:
Reflection #3 - Fill out this section on your Notes Sheet
Beware of questions that:

details.htmlContent:
Are actually advice masquerading as a question:

Example:

Don’t you take notes in class so you can review them later? (which implies they should)

details.text: or

details.htmlContent:
Leading the student to a specific answer you want to hear:

Example:

You understand this, right? (it would feel awkward to say ‘no’)

details.text: Paraphrasing

details.htmlContent:
Paraphrase is to say back to the person what they just said but to pick up on the key idea or summarize the main thought.

“Let me make sure I’m understanding what you mean” [and then go on to summarize]

“It sounds like you’re saying” [and then offer a quick summary]
details.alt: Two women talking to each other

details.text: We paraphrase to make sure we understand the other person and to gain clarity if we don’t. Paraphrasing also allows the person you are working with to hear their own words aloud, and said back to them. This can be an important technique in helping a student clarify their meaning or identify where they’re confused.

Remember: We don’t paraphrase to improve on the idea, to change what they said, or to offer a suggestion. It’s a tool designed to check if you’re understanding what they said, not to offer your own thinking.
Click on each peer educator to hear them demonstrate some paraphrasing language.

browser.htmlContent: Good leaders ask questions in order to reflect on past experiences, receive feedback, and identify future goals for the team
In your personal life with family, friends, or significant others, you can seek clarification in order to avoid misunderstandings
Supervisors can use validation to motivate and encourage their employees
Choose a tab above to display more information

details.text: Time to practice!
Review the text below and practice paraphrasing.

Student: “It’s taking me hours and hours to do the homework. I start a problem and look at it and I think I know how to do it, but then part way through I get confused and get stuck. So I move on to the next problem. But the whole homework assignment is like that and in the end I’ve spent three hours and didn’t get a single problem done!”
How would you paraphrase this? Click to reveal two options (below)

cards.text: Peer Educator (paraphrasing): "So, you've been putting a lot of time into the homework problems, but on each one of them you get stuck somewhere?"
Peer Educator (paraphrasing): "What I hear you say is that a lot of time is put in, but it's hard to complete the problems because you get stuck when working through each of them?"

details.text: Reflection #4 - Fill out this section on your Notes Sheet
You may be wondering "what if I want to make a suggestion or give particular advice?"
This isn’t to say that you should never make an outright suggestion or recommendation.  Suggestions can help offer other ideas or help a student see options. But...
If you haven’t given the student a chance to think yet, it can limit the effectiveness of your work by:

cards.text: Taking away the chance for the student to have their own success and build confidence in their ability because you are doing the thinking for them.
Generating resistance when students push back on suggestions if they don't feel heard.
Inhibiting following through as people are more likely to take action based on ideas they have created themselves.

details.text: There are okay, good and better ways to offer suggestions and recommendations. Try to build in choice and don’t assume what you have in mind will work for them.

browser.htmlContent:
Be transparent about the suggestion.

"I'd recommend trying this ______"

Share from your perspective, don't assume it'll work for them.

"I like to do it this way ____; but I also know it doesn't work for everyone."

OR

"I've heard other students do ___; do you think that would be helpful?"

Ask for permission. Check with them after.

"I have an idea that might work for you - would you like to hear it?" (then share from your perspective) (then ask for their take on it)
Select okay, good or better to learn more...

details.text: Let's try a few different approaches
Click on the category that matches the quote shown below. Remember, the good and better options leave room for student choice!

questions.text: "I've heard students look at textbook examples, would that be helpful?"
"I'd reccomend reviewing your notes first, then checking the textbook."
"Would you like to hear an idea? What if we look at examples from your notes?"
Great job! You've successfully matched everything.

details.text: So now that we’ve talked generally about different types of questions, let’s continue on to the next section.
We often interpret what others say through our own experiences, lenses, and perspectives. Seeking clarification is one way to establish trust and rapport with those with whom you work.
We seek clarification as a way of understanding the other person and not assuming we understand based on our own interpretations.
The risk in not clarifying is that you can misinterpret or misunderstand the other person.
Here’s an example of what we mean:
A friend asked for your help to find an apple.

details.imageAlt: A bunch of granny smith apples.

details.text: You may have had a particular apple variety come to mind with the question. But which type of apple is your friend looking for?  What are they going to use the apple for?
More than apples...
The apple example is pretty small, but these different lenses and perspectives can translate to bigger life experiences.
Follow the link to Pellegrino Ricarddi’s TED Talk on cross cultural communication. Watch the 8:14 - 9:15 min segment.
After watching the video, consider the following:
How might different lenses and perspectives play out in peer education? And how does curiosity play into these different perspectives?
Here’s one way this idea translates to peer education...
As an example, if a student says ‘I have a question about math’ there may be numerous ways we make meaning of or interpret that statement. Click on the numbers below to explore.
"I have a question about math."

columns.text: "I didn't read or go to class. Can you tell me what is important from this chapter."
"I've been up all night studying and I don't understand this."
"I mostly understand this concept, but have a few questions."
"I can't study at home with my kids around and coming to tutoring is a place I can study."
"I'm not feeling confident, can you watch me work this problem?"

details.text: To prevent miscommunications or misunderstanding:
Seek clarification and ask questions.

Approaching the conversation with curiosity can be helpful in both allowing you to check your understanding, and also to gain more insight into what the other person meant, or at least pause your assumptions or interpretations.
How do we seek clarification?
Prompts or questions like the these may help you clarify what the student means:
Tell me more about that.
Could you tell me more about that?
Would you mind clarifying what you meant by _______?
Could you be more specific?
What do you mean by that?
What I think I heard you say was ______, is that correct?
Think about your own style: what phrases resonate with you?
Seeking clarification can help establish trust and rapport. So can validation. Let’s continue!
One of the ways we support the student in seeing their own capacity as a learner is through offering validation. This section provides information and examples on how to validate students.
details.alt: Thumbs up graphic with a checkmark in the middle

details.text: In a 2011 article, researchers Susana Muñoz and Laura Rendon define validation as  “the intentional, proactive affirmation of students.”
It sounds like:
“You can do this!”
“You’re doing great work”
“That was great, how you [ specific action ] just now”
What do we validate and how often?
Validation is different than praise or compliments. It’s designed to focus on effort and process.
Click on the examples below to see how a peer educator might phrase validation in each case.

cards.text: "Yes! On the second attempt, you fixed that mistake - nice job!"
"I want to acknowledge you've put a lot of time into making that study guide!"
"I think it's really helpful that you realized that strategy wasn't working."
"That's a great observation! It sounds like you don't feel as confident with that topic - recognizing that is an important skill!"

details.text: We can also normalize feelings, acknowledge experiences and share our own experiences.
Examples:
Remember that normalizing feelings does not mean you need to agree - it is a way to acknowledge the experience that person had. It conveys “I hear you and I understand.”
details.alt: Two students doing homework with a laptop

details.text: In the video below, hear some examples of how peer educators validate students or normalize their experiences:
Reflection #5 - Fill out this section on your Notes Sheet
Why is validation important?

There are experiences throughout our lives that can make us doubt our capacity or abilities. In college, this can be amplified by tests, interactions with someone who doesn’t support you, offhand comments from peers, and other environmental factors.
Your goal as a peer educator is to not only avoid adding to that doubt, but to do what you can to counteract it; to help the student see what they’re doing well and confirm their ability to learn.
You can help students feel capable of learning!
Building awareness of our own assumptions, perspectives, and ideas can better position us to check those assumptions and practice empathy when working with others

We all have thoughts and assumptions in reaction to what we encounter.  Being aware of our assumptions as we ask thoughtful questions, seek clarification, and offer validation is important as we work towards our objectives for each session.
Therefore, it’s important for us to listen to ourselves, become more aware of our own thoughts, and recognize the impact our thoughts have on how we help a student.
Our Inner Voice
We see the world through our own experiences, lenses, and perspectives. In the example below, note how the peer educator on the right is experiencing the session.

cards.revealText: Tutor: "I think this session is going really well!"
cards.text: Student: "This tutor is so nice, but I still don't understand!"

cards.revealText: Tutor: "He came in so prepared; he seems really on top of it."
cards.text: Student: "How do I tell the tutor I'm stuck?"

cards.revealText: Tutor: "It seems like he's really understanding the content!"
cards.text: Student: "Oh my, this is going to be a really hard test!"

details.text: This example demonstrates how easy it can be to misinterpret a situation. The peer educator’s assumptions get in the way of understanding how the student is experiencing the session. This example is pretty simple, but there may be some instances when your assumptions can get in the way of working effectively with a student.
In addition to seeking clarity in the moment, you can continually work on identifying and checking your assumptions.
Peer Educator Voice
Continuing the work outside of sessions...
As we become more aware of our assumptions, we can:
Explore what we believe and determine the accuracy of those beliefs
Check assumptions by determining how accurate our assumptions are
Take informed actions based on the quality of evidence we were able to gather
Change or expand our beliefs as we learn from others
What can we do within in a session...
Engage in activities that help you connect with the students you are working with.
Listen
Clarify
Validate
Practice empathy
As you ask questions and really listen to what the student is saying, consider times you experienced similar situations emotions or thoughts.
Practice care - for yourself and those you are working with
Making assumptions is something we all do from time to time. When you do make a wrong assumption, acknowledge the mistake and then move on, taking the learning with you.
As with the other Unit 1 topics, building awareness is ongoing work. For now, let’s tie this all together!
Let’s Review! What are the foundational elements of working together?

accordions.html: The foundational elements we discussed in this unit can help you build an authentic and caring relationship with your peer. Caring positively impacts the learning you do together, enhances sense of belonging and reinforces student success.
Preparing yourself to listen, demonstrating that you are listening and clarifying what you are actually hearing show your peer that you are mentally and physically present.
Asking the right questions not only help you build a positive relationship with your peers but also empowers them to engage, to think and to take ownership of their learning.

You build trust and rapport with your peers when you clarify what you think you heard from them and/or confirm their goals through their own lenses and perspectives, as to avoid working from misconceptions or eliminate misunderstandings.
Validating the student efforts and normalizing feelings is important to counteract self-doubt. You can help your peers see their true accomplishments and bring that to the forefront.

You cannot escape your own inner voice, lenses and perspectives, but you can be very aware of them and when they can detract from your peer learning experience. Be aware of your assumptions and refocus on your student.

details.text: Wrapping Up Unit 1
These foundational elements of working together can give you a framework to build a caring relationship and to focus on the authentic experiences and goals of your peers.
TBefore you move on to Unit 2, click here for a handout with the main takeaways from Unit 1 - a tool you can continue to use in your work as a peer educator.
Click the button to download and print the “Unit 1 Take-away Sheet”
Unit 1 Take away sheet
Download it, save it, print it! Have this at hand for a quick reference sheet when you need a reminder of the foundational elements of building a relationship and working with another person.
References list and learning materials associated with this unit.

Looking ahead! Unit 2: “Empowering Students Through Collaborative Learning” is next. In this unit we move from understanding how to work together to understanding how you collaborate with the student to accomplish learning within the session.
You’ve Completed Unit 1

sections.title: Unit 2: Empowering Students through Collaborative Learning

details.text: This unit explores some foundational elements we use when supporting another student’s learning.
details.alt: Two ladies working together on a laptop

details.text: Before you begin Unit 2, please click on the “ Unit 2 Reflection Guide” link below to download/print a note-taking sheet.
Click the button to download and print the Unit 2 Handout
At the beginning of this training, we set up three key objectives for each peer education interaction or session. Your goals are to:
Support the student in recognizing their own capacity as a learner.
Engage the student in thinking strategies and activities to master content.
Help the student to identify tools and resources available to them.

In this unit our focus is on the second goal. There are many ways to learn information and skills associated with course content, so we will emphasize having a general understanding of how learning happens, acknowledging our own learning behaviors and preferences, and being open to and flexible about the different ways students may approach learning.
There are many ways to learn.

Within one course you may get information in lecture, read about concepts in a textbook, watch videos, complete practice problems or online homework, and more. Each of these activities has a different role to play in how we acquire and retain new information.

Additionally, each person has a different way of learning that works best for them. We’re not talking about learning styles; we’re talking about how each person brings their prior experiences and skills to the learning environment. We help others learn by maximizing their strengths and assisting them in building new learning strategies.

In some learning environments we may experience a passive model of learning where the educator is giving the information to the student, who receives it. John Bransford (How People Learn, 2000) called this “teaching by telling,” and Paolo Friere (Pedagogy of the Oppressed, 1970) talked about the “banking model of education.”
This model for learning creates a passive interaction because it does not require the student do anything active with the information.
details.caption: Photo by Gradikaa on Unsplash

details.text: In contrast, research from the field of education and learning sciences argues that a more active approach makes learning more effective and collaborative for the student.
Terry Doyle and Todd Zakrajsek (2013) write that learning new material requires active engagement with the information, such as:
Finding connections and patterns in information
Applying new information to a problem or question you haven’t seen before
Practice, practice, practice!
Knowing that learning new material requires active engagement, we can use our role and interactions intentionally to create space for students to engage.
Doyle and Zakrajsek (2013) go on to summarize:

“The primary message from neuroscience researchers is relatively simple: ‘The one who does the work does the learning’ (Doyle 2008, p. 63). Only when you practice, read, write, think, talk, collaborate, and reflect, does your brain make permanent connections. Your teachers [and peer educators] cannot do this for you”
(Doyle & Zakrajsek, 2013, p.12)
Reflection #1 - Fill out this section on your Notes Sheet

So, when we do the work of thinking, our brain is actively learning new information and practicing it for later retrieval. If you do the work for the student, the student will not experience the full benefit of long-term learning.
When we shift from the passive model then the learning process can become a collaborative endeavor with the student. Collaboration in peer education may look like:

columns.imageAlt: Two students working on a laptop
columns.text: Working through a problem together - alternating steps.

columns.imageAlt: Two students working on a white board
columns.text: The students creating a concept map on the whiteboard, while you ask prompting questions like "what else?"

columns.imageAlt: A girl working on a laptop
columns.text: Answering a question from a practice test independently and then comparing answers.
Comparing answers and discussing how you each approached the question.

details.text: As a peer educator, you have a chance to help the student engage actively in the content – to help them do the work of learning. Not only will this produce better learning for the student, but the collaborative interaction has the potential to be a more empowering experience for the student as well.
Let’s learn a bit more about what your collaborative role in the learning process may look like by examining some of the theories and techniques that describe this work.
We mentioned that collaborative interactions can both produce better learning and empower students, but what does that collaboration look like?
As a starting place, collaborative learning relies heavily on the techniques you learned in Unit 1 (asking questions, paraphrasing, validating, etc.).
In addition, this section will provide a brief introduction to some other techniques:
Identifying the Zone of Proximal Development (ZPD), which builds awareness of how student development and growth happens
“Scaffolding” activities, which helps students build skills and independence over time
“Investigating together,” which demonstrates how to facilitate learning through questions and prompts

The Zone of Proximal Development (ZPD) concept was introduced by Psychologist Lev Vygotsky in the 1930’s. Vygotsky posited that development often occurs in the space between what a learner can do independently and what a learner can’t yet do, even with help.
Zone of Proximal Development
Things you can do on your own.
Things you can do with some help.
Things you can't do yet, even with help.
